results.title: Jumping molecules!
results.creator_credit: Christopher Haws, Michael Latham and Landmark Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Start Here: Adventures into Science”.
Konrad, the kitchen robot, shows how the energy in heat may be used to demonstrate the fundamentals of physics. Focuses on temperature and presents experiments using common household materials involving the kitchen refrigerator, cold water and hot water.

results.title: Make a noise
results.creator_credit: Christopher Haws, Michael Latham and Landmark Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Start Here: Adventures into Science”.
Explains what sound is and why some sounds are musical. Shows how to experiment with vibrations and to create music. This programme is suitable for upper primary science.

results.title: The Invisible force
results.creator_credit: Christopher Haws, Michael Latham and Landmark Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Start Here: Adventures into Science”.
Konrad, the kitchen robot, shows students that gravity and friction determine how everything on earth behaves during movement. Using simple experiments that can be reproduced in class or at home, he reveals the nature of the forces acting upon us.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher Haws, Michael Latham and Landmark Films

results.title: Mix a material
results.creator_credit: Christopher Haws, Michael Latham, Landmark Films and Video Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Start Here: Adventures into Science”.
Looks at why materials bend, stretch and break. Demonstrates experiments to show the behaviour of molecular lattices in everyday substances from chocolate to rubber ballons.

results.title: The Amazing magnet
results.creator_credit: Christopher Haws, Michael Latham and Video Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Start Here: Adventures into Science”.
This program presents a range of experiments that demonstrate the forces of magnets. Illustrates the nature and properties of magnetic fields, briefly traces the history of the compass, shows how the earth behaves like a magnet and presents some modern applications of electro- magnets.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher Haws, Michael Latham and Video Arts
results.description:

results.title: Air at work
results.creator_credit: Christopher Haws, Michael Latham and Video Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Start Here: Adventures into Science”.
This program presents experiments that demonstrate the varying forces that are created when air moves. Demonstrates the theory of flight and the creation of weather patterns.

results.title: Rainbow serpent
results.creator_credit: Richard Guthrie, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs
results.brief_description: Presents the cultural heritage of the first Australians through their own eyes. In an unbiased, unpatronising light it paints a realistic picture of a society whose tarnished image was created by those who supposedly made this country - the European settlers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Guthrie, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs

group_works.title: Baboon social organization
group_works.creator_credit: C. Cameron Macauley and University of California, Los Angeles

results.title: Baboon social organization
results.creator_credit: C. Cameron Macauley and University of California, Los Angeles
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Baboon Social Life”.
Analyses the nature of the interdependence within a baboon troop and its close relation to baboon ecology. Discusses the role of central males, peripheral males, mothers with infants and juveniles. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.
results.creator_credit_for_label: C. Cameron Macauley and University of California, Los Angeles

results.title: Man: a course of study
results.brief_description: The course of study is designed for upper primary or lower secondary level but can be introduced effectively at any level. It deals with the basic questions: What is human about human beings? How did they get that way? How can they be made more so?
